name: electricity production, lignite | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7413/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity in an average lignite power plant in Taiwan in 2012. "Lignite" is used as representant for "brown coal", which includes sub-bituminous coal and lignite according to the definition of the IEA electricity information 2014. (IEA. 2014. Electricity Information 2014. ISBN 978-92-64-21692-1. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR).);All exchanges in this dataset except for emissions of SO2, NOx and particles are production-weighted averages of the figures in the datasets in ecoinvent version two, which are valid for the following 10 countries: AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK. The exception values are production-weighted averages of version 2 countries and the new countries in version 3 (AU, CA, CL, ID, IN, KR, MX, MY, PE, RU, TH, TR, TW, TZ, UA, ZA)All exchanges in this dataset except for emissions of SO2, NOx and particles have been overtaken from the global dataset, which in their turn are production-weighted averages of the figures in the datasets in ecoinvent version two, which are valid for the following 10 countries: AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK. The exception values have been determined using a bottom-up approach. It consists in the collection of information about country-specific single plants.;Comments on the inventory data of emissions: ; - for the assessment of main characteristics (sulphur and ash content of coal, efficiency of the plant) and CO2 a bottom-up approach has been used. It consists in the collection of information about single plants. ;- Halogene emissions have been estimated on the basis of the content of the species in the country-specific coal input mix, assuming average retention rates.  ; - For CO and particle emissions average values for the former UCTE are included (Union for the Coordination of the Transmission of Electricity, since 2009 replaced by ENTSO-E European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity).  ; - The country specific emissions of N2O depend on the share of DeNOx.  - Emissions of trace elements were calculated by means of a formula (CORINAIR) using the ash content in the country-specific coal input mix and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants, taking into account the share of DeSOx installed. ; - Emission of uranium and thorium radioactive isotopes were assumed proportional to the corresponding element emitted with particles; the other non-gaseous radioactive isotopes of the uranium and thorium decay chain were assumed proportional to the emitted U-238 or Th-232. ; - The emission of gaseous radon and K-40 are taken from the literature.;IEA. 2009. Coal information, 2009 edition. Documentation for beyond 2020 files. International Energy Agency.;European Environment Agency (1991) CORINAIR Inventory; VOC"s Default Emission Factors;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

From the constructed lignite power plant ready to produce electricity. 

From reception of lignite and operating materials at power plant gate.

This activity ends with 1kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

This dataset includes: 
 - all operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants. 

 - Particle removal (dedusting of the flue gas)
  - Desulfurisation and denitrification. These processes are described in separate modules; it can be decided by changing the values of NOx and SOx retained whether and how much DeNOx and DeSOx are installed. 
 - Cooling: It is assumed that all plants use wet cooling with a cooling tower. No cooling tower is included in this dataset (will be implemented in future versions)
- Loss of feed water 
 - Losses from gross electricity production, e.g. for internal use


This dataset doesn"t include 
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets
 - transformation of the electricity produced
 - The disposal of non-recycled ashes is modelled separately.
 - Use of fuel oil for startup, as this can be neglected for lignite power plants because these are run for a long time (2-3 years) without being shut down.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2012.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: POWER PLANT:;Lignite power plant input is a dataset which consists of a mix of 30% 100MW power plant and 70% 500MW power plant. The plants are used for basic load with 6000 hours of operation at full capacity per year. The plants are assumed to operate 200000 hours during its lifetime.;OTHER DATA:;{{children_only_technology}}; - Share of installed capacity with desulfurisation: 20% (rough estimation based on sulfur mass balance; - Average efficiency of desulfurisation installations: 92% (rough estimation based on Dones et al. 2007; - Share of installed capacity with denitrification: 73% (figure based on IEA 2012 ); - Average efficiency of denitrification installations: 80% (estimation based on Dones et al. 2007, p.128. Valid for selective catalytic reaction systems); - Share of installed capacity with particle filters: 98% (figure based on IEA 2012 ); - Average efficiency of particle filters: no data;Sources : ;1)	Victoria: http://new.dpi.vic.gov.au/energy-future/our-energy-story/energy-in-victoria/resources-in-victoria-map;2)	Queensland: http://www.dme.qld.gov.au/Energy/power_stations.cfm;3)	New South Wales: http://www.industry.nsw.gov.au/energy/electricity/generation;4)	Map of Fossil Fuel Power Stations in Australia, DEWHA, http://www.ga.gov.au/fossil_fuel/;5)	IEA 2012. Coal Power Database. International Energy Agency Clean Coal Centre, London ;6)	Australian National Pollutant Inventory, http://www.npi.gov.au/ ;7)	IEA/OECD. 2010. Electricity Information 2010. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR). Part IV. Detailed OECD Electricity And Heat Data.;8) Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Most of the exchanges were extrapolated through production-weighted averages of the datasets of the following 10 countries: AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK.

The original data were valid for the burning of 1MJ of lignite. In this dataset, the values are scaled to the net output of 1kWh of electricity, based on the electrical efficiency.

flow.name: electricity, high voltage
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description:
Assumption. Data overtaken from conditions in Thailand. Thailand value: Calculated value. Based on the total particle emissions, global production-weighted average of ecoinvent version 2 countries. 
The shares of the three particulates classes are taken from Dones et al 2007, Tab. 9.39 p. 130 and amount to
-	particulates >10um: 5%
-	particulates 2.5-10 um: 10%
-	particulates < 2.5 um: 85%

Global total emissions without any particulate filter were calculated to amount to 207 g/kWh and were then figured together with the share of installed particle filter and efficiency of the filter (see technology comment for details).

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from lignite, based on the value for burning 1MJ of lignite. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and emission values of 10 countries 
(AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK) (Röder et al. 2007) 
Country emissions values based on literature. 

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

flow.name: Radium-226
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Calculated value departing from the installed desulfurisation, its efficiency and the SO2 emitted in the air (see Technology Comment for details). According to Röder et al. 2007, about 20-60% of the sulfur contained in the coal don"t turn into SO2 but can be found in the ash. A factor of 40% is taken here for calculations.

defaultProvider.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description: Literature value/calculated value. Cooling water, decarbonised, for the cooling water circuit lost when producing 1kWh of electricity from lignite, based on the value for burning 1MJ of lignite. Röder et al. 2007, Tab. 9.65 and Tab. 9.66, p. 160f. These tables give an amount of 0.15 kg/MJ burned, which is valid for the assumption of 75% wet cooling and 25% run-through cooling. However, this revised dataset assumes 100% wet cooling.

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from lignite, based on the value for burning 1MJ of lignite. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and emission values of 10 countries

flow.name: Propane
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Rough assumption. No data were available in the Power Database, so that the values for Thailand were overtaken. These values are calculated values, based on the IEA Clean Coal Centre Coal Power Database. Calculation was made with the sulfur content of the coal used (weight % as received), the input of coal (Mt/y), the efficiency of the desulfurisation and the capacity of the power plants.  According to Röder et al. 2007, about 20-60% of the sulfur contained in the coal don"t turn into SO2 but can be found in the ash. A factor of 40% is taken here for calculations.

flow.name: Potassium-40
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. At the moment, the lignite power plant input consists out of mix of a 100MWe power plant (30%) and a 500MWe power plant (70%). 
For this calculation, 6000 load hours per year are assumed. It is assumed that a total of 200"000h is reached during the lifetime. A capacity of 500MW is taken for the calculation.

flow.name: Hydrocarbons, aliphatic, alkanes, unspecified
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Ash remaining when producing 1kWh of electricity from lignite, based on the value for burning 1MJ of lignite. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and ash values 10 countries 
(AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK). These values were valid for the ash being disposed off. Now, total amount of ash has been calculated (disposed+recycled) with the data in Tab. 9.69 p. 165 in Röder et al. 2007. Country ash values calculated from mass balance. Globally, 6% of the lignite ash are recycled, 94% go to disposal.

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

flow.name: lignite ash

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Emissions when producing 1kWh of electricity from lignite, based on the value for burning 1MJ of lignite. Weighted average with electricity production data (Itten&Frischknecht 2012) and emission values of 10 countries 
(AT, BA, CZ, DE, ES, FR, HU, PL, SI, SK) (Röder et al. 2007) 
Country emissions values based on literature. 

Source: 
Itten R. and Frischknecht R. (2012) Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid. ESU-services Ltd., Uster, Switzerland.

flow.name: Mercury II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Assumption. Data overtaken from conditions in Thailand. Thailand value: Calculated value. Based on the total particle emissions, global production-weighted average of ecoinvent version 2 countries. 
The shares of the three particulates classes are taken from Dones et al 2007, Tab. 9.39 p. 130 and amount to
-	particulates >10um: 5%
-	particulates 2.5-10 um: 10%
-	particulates < 2.5 um: 85%

Global total emissions without any particulate filter were calculated to amount to 207 g/kWh and were then figured together with the share of installed particle filter and efficiency of the filter (see technology comment for details).
